sections.content: 📚  The Pr√§sens tense
Introduction

The Konjunktiv II Pr√§teritum, also known as the subjunctive II past tense, is a unique verb form in German that used to express hypothetical scenarios and indirect speech. While it might seem daunting at first, understanding its formation and usage will open doors to a deeper understanding of German grammar.
The Konjunktiv II Pr√§teritum is mostly used on a few verbs that must be memorised. On the rest of verbs the Konjunktiv II form with "werden" will be used.
Usage
We use the Konjunktiv II Pr√§teritum tense to:

items.text: Politeness: : it softens the speech when making polite requests or suggestions.
General Hypotheticals: it addresses conditions that are imaginary or contrary to fact, not necessarily situated in the past
Wishes: It expresses wishes or scenarios that are desired yet not real.

sections.content: Conjugation
Regular verbs

Add the endings -te, -test, -te, -ten, -tet, -ten to the stem of the verb. Importantly, for Konjunktiv II, this is the same form as the Pr√§teritum tense (simple past) tense but used in a subjunctive mood. For example, "spielen" (to play) becomes: ich spielte, du spieltest, (er) (sie) (es) spielte, wir spielten, ihr spieltet, sie spielten.

table.audio: ich spielte, du spieltest, (er) (sie) (es) spielte, wir spielten, ihr spieltet, sie spielten.

example.translation: (If I had more time, I would play the piano every day)

Irregular verbs

Certain verbs are more likely to be used in the Konjunktiv II Pr√§teritum because they often express desires or theoretical possibilities. They are all irregular and the conjugations should be learnt. Forming the Partizip II
The main verb of the Perfekt tense will take the Partizip II (past participle) form. In English, it is equivalent to forms like "eaten," "gone," or "written."
The formation of Partizip II depends on whether the verb is regular (weak), irregular (strong), or a mixed verb (with characteristics of both).
Regular verbs
We will follow the next steps:

1. Remove the infinitive ending (-en or -n):
    • machen (to do) ‚Üí mach
  2. Add the prefix ge- to the stem:
    • mach ‚Üí ge-mach
  3. Add the suffix "-t":
    • ge-mach ‚Üí gemacht
So, the Partizip II of "$__machen-machen[verb-link-hover]__$" is "gemacht."

More examples:

  • lernen (to learn) ‚Üí gelernt
  • spielen (to play) ‚Üí gespielt
Irregular verbs
For most of the irregular verbs we will follow the next steps:

1. Change the stem vowel (if necessary, as per the verb's pattern) and remove the infinitive ending (-en or -n):
    • schreiben (to write) ‚Üí schrieb- (past stem)
  2. Add the prefix ge- to the stem:
    • schrieb ‚Üí ge-schrieben
  3. Add the suffix "-en":
    • ge-schrieben ‚Üí geschrieben
So, the Partizip II of "$__schreiben-schreiben[verb-link-hover]__$" is "geschrieben."

More examples:

  • sehen (to see) ‚Üí gesehen
  • sprechen (to speak) ‚Üí gesprochen
